Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Situation2: They spot a child struggling in the deep end where swimming is restricted.
Story:
I was halfway through folding the mountain of laundry on our bed, the scent of fresh detergent filling the room. My spouse had asked me, just this morning, to help out more around the house, and I promised I’d get the laundry done before my shift. I could hear the dryer humming, a reminder of the chores still waiting. But as I glanced at the clock, I realized I was running late for my lifeguard duty at the pool. 

When I arrived, the pool was crowded and noisy. I scanned the water, my mind still on the laundry at home. Suddenly, I spotted a child in the deep end, flailing—right where swimming was off-limits. My training kicked in, but so did the memory of my spouse’s tired voice, asking for help. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing on me: the expectation to keep my family running smoothly, and the responsibility to keep others safe. My heart pounded as I stood at the edge, torn between the demands of home and the urgent call of my duty at the pool.
